Ask HN: Name for the dynamic when new hires outperform those with seniority?
text:
I was reading a thread on HN the other day that introduced me to the concept of the "Dead Sea Effect" in companies that can't retain talent. The simple summary of the effect is this: if your company is unappealing in some way and can't/won't retain high performers, the high performers will leave and the company will become dominated by low performers. (The original article has been linked to a LOT if you search the archives, but here's another link for the curious: http://brucefwebster.com/2008/04/11/the-wetware-crisis-the-dead-sea-effect/)

The dead sea effect reminds me of something I've seen firsthand at a few startups, and I'm hoping that somebody here can let me know if it has a name because I'd love to read up about it more.

The phenomenon of interest works something like this:

- A small startup doesn't have the means/clout to hire top talent at every position, so the make-do with some early employees that are poor-to-average performers. - Like the dead-sea effect, those poor-to-average performers will cling to the company because the don't have other options. - If the company starts to grow, two things happen: a) those early employees can use their seniority to move into leadership positions and b) the company starts attracting higher quality new hires. Resulting in departments with lots of talented new hires at the bottom of the org chart and poor-performing (but long-tenured) employees firmly entrenched at the top.

The result is that if a startup undergoes rapid growth/expansion, you can have a situation where employee seniority is inversely related with their performance.

Show HN: A Python script to convert DocBook books to QtHelp
text:
I usually write my user documentation using DocBook. For my recent applications built on top of Qt (e.g. PaletteWB (www.palettewb.com)), I needed something that generates in-app help pages. db2qthelp does this.

Any criticism or interest is appreciated.

Show HN: Guess The Year (of release for music videos)
text:
Hi everyone!

When I was younger, my friend and I used to play a game where we would watch MTV music videos and then try to guess the year of release. Now I’ve turned this childhood memory into a real game as an attempt to put my recently learned programming skills to use. I invite you to play along because I promise, you’ll have a blast!

Let me know if you have any questions.

Cheers!

Ask HN: How can I become a Microsoft “Managed Customer”?
text:
Hello, so I have a startup https://aidev.codes. Its a bit rough but if people are able to look past the lack of UI polish, I have connected the core technology, and many improvements in the works, such as moving to dialog-based and adding knowledgebase support (which the main part is finished). Currently I have to default to using text-davinci-003 instead of code-davinci-002 (Codex) which is the code-specific model. Because OpenAI's API is limited to 10-20 requests per minute for those models.

Now with the announcement about the partnership with Microsoft, apparently the code-davinci-002 is moving to "Azure OpenAI" and they tout it as "generally available". But in fact, it is limited to "managed customers and partners". You have to apply here:

- https://customervoice.microsoft.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=v4j5cvGGr0GRqy180BHbR7en2Ais5pxKtso_Pz4b1_xUOFA5Qk1UWDRBMjg0WFhPMkIzTzhKQ1dWNyQlQCN0PWcu

Would anyone be willing to act as an investor or partner to help me get the contacts or funding needed to keep my startup alive? I feel like I am going to just be locked out unless I have some "in" with Microsoft or access to more funds to become an "enterprise" "managed" customer or something. Also due to lack of funds I have to take small client projects related to the other website in order to stay afloat. I think this is hampering me to an incredible extent compared to less-skilled developers that have funding to hire more engineers and access the models at scale.

You can contact me at runvnc@gmail.com

My github is runvnc. I also have another website https://algonfts.art and have been building small startups for more than 12 years.

Ask HN: Would you trust car insurance trackers?
text:
So my Geico (save your 15 minutes) rate went up significantly for no reason. If I use their tracking app "Drive Easy" they are offering 20% discount (pretty significant). I thought why not?

It ALWAYS wants to see my location It wants access to my health and fitness data

I obviously can't justify the discount by giving up my privacy. My wife says I am paranoid and she doesn't see anything wrong. I am assuming most people won't.

Soon Geico (DON'T WASTE YOUR 15 MINUTES) will have everything they need. They promise they won't use the data to raise rates, only to give discounts but in few years or even sooner, they will cancel high risks and then make them pay higher rates to join. Who the hell is going to read 100 pages of terms.

All these insurance companies have apps like these.
